description: From Renaissance Latin nihilitas, from Latin nihil (“nothing”).

entries.meaning: The state or fact of being nothing; nothingness, nullity; nonexistence. [from 17th c.]
examples: Paeans and even poems have been written to the esoteric nature of the smallest building blocks of matter: how they manifest as everywhere and nowhere, seem to have come out of emptiness, and at the ultimate level seem to be distilled from pure nihility.

entries.meaning: (obsolete, countable) A nonexistent thing; nothing. [18th–19th c.]
examples: Della Crusca says all past Actions are Nihilities; & that the immediate Instant is the whole of human Existence—A bad Accᵗ of it surely!
